page.title: 15SKIPSEA CASTLE
page.content: Skipsea Castle is well preserved so far as it's earthworks are concerned. It was built by Dru de la Beuvriere soon after the Norman Conquest. The motte is forty-six feet in height and was originally an island separated from the bailey to which it was connected by a timber bridge.The sheet of water was known as the mere of Skipsea. It was demolished in 1220 in the reign of Henry III. Today,the motte is a hill on which about a dozen trees are growing. Only a small section of stone wall remains. From the top,you have a good view all around. You can see Flamboro'Head and many miles inland. The ancient British earthworks still almost surround the motte. There is a legend that if you run around the motte 7 times while the church bell rings midnight then {OLD MOLLIE}(a ghost) will appear.
